Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen so I'm 
standing in the backyard of my parents home in

just fell in love with its simplicity it's sort of

flavors I'm making kao kluk pla too so kao 
is rice kluk means to sort of toss everything

together and pla too is Thai short mackerel so 
I know that I'm going to be taking this dish back

to Canada and make it over and over again because 
it's really simple and really delicious so one of

the things though that I need to get first one of 
my ingredients is green mango so sour green mango

is one of the major component of this dish if you 
can't find it don't worry I'll talk about how to

substitute but luckily in my home in Thailand 
we've got this massive mango tree and perfectly

I've got some green mango green mango that is 
ready to be picked so in order to pick those

I need this thing here this is what I call my saw 
you've got a basket with a little blade right over

here and that's used to cut the fruit off of the

I think it's perfect so you want green mango that

that's not going to work so let's see if I can

go ah got it yay perfect bug check before I reach

in the kitchen so my version of calculus who is 
basically a simple garlic fried rice that's served

with some Thai short mackerel and some fresh 
herbs and vegetables around the fight and then

when you eat it you get to do the fun of mixing 
it up yours so it's a very simple dish that to

talk about our vegetables that go on the side so 
I've got here some shallots thinly sliced shallot

so these are Thai shallots ooh they're tiny and 
some green onions and cilantro you don't like

to answer you can skip it I've got some wine this 
is a tie line so it's very small but other lines

will do just fine the green mango we just got 
some chilies chopped up and I've also got some

long beans I just want to show you a whole one 
because in Thailand I find they're longer and

also lighter in color but whatever kinds of long 
beans you've got will be just fine I'm just going

to cut these into small small little pieces 
so it'll mix well into our rice and give it a

little bit of a crunch so I have to say that this 
is not exactly the way I had it at the restaurant

but you know I'm making it thinner now I'm going 
to deal with my green mango so I'm going to deal

with this exactly the same way I deal with my 
green papaya in my papaya salad we want to peel

it first best with a sharp peeler which this is 
not I'm only going to need half because this is

very sour okay and then with a sharp knife which 
this is also not it's not my kitchen I have to

kind of make do it whatever I have this is going 
to make a bunch of decisions incisions chop chop

chop what's your thing is it is a little scarier 
than a papaya because it's so much smaller and

then you just slice it and one of the things that 
might happen if you're don't make a deep enough

incisions and then they get kind of stuck together 
in a big piece like this no big deal as long as

most of them are shredded up you'll be fine you 
can always go back and you know we chopped those

other ones I think that's good enough for now look 
how beautiful these shredded pieces are and if you

julienne any other way it just does not look like 
this you don't have sour green mango oh I almost

forgot what you can do is use carrot shredded like 
this I wouldn't use this method with a carrot very

skinny but julienne your Terrace and let it soak 
in some lime juice and allow the acidity of the

lines penetrate at the carrots and you get sort of 
a similar thing similar you know similar feel Tex

your flavor okay so now my vegetables are 
ready my mackerel so this is flat whoo it's

a very sort of homey rustic fish widely available 
very inexpensive in Thailand however if you can't

find this you can use regular mackerel so when 
you buy flats who in Thailand they always come

already cooked and already salt it and I believe 
that just traditionally how they prevented the

fish from going back too quickly so when you get 
it all you have to do is sear them just to get a

nice golden brown color on the skin I like to put 
quite a bit of oil so the oil reaches all the you

know nooks and crannies of the fish and if you're 
using regular macro you can just get fillets and

pan sear that until it's cooked and golden brown 
that's all okay so now what I'm gonna do is break

the flesh apart into smaller pieces and debone 
it so this is sort of the hardest part of using

flat who is there is a lot of boned so I like 
to just take the head off first and then on the

back pull off the fin and you'll get you'll feel 
it there's bones that run all along the backbone

so we just pull that off now I'm going to remove 
the belly fins which also has tiny little bones

attached to it and then I'm just going to split 
the fillet apart a eggs there our egg the Wonder

is so big and then I pull this off nice and neat 
and then the belly also has sort of the ribcage

of the fish so you want to remove these big guys 
as well if you like the eggs you can have the eggs

it's really fatty I find it a little bitter so 
I don't love it there's also bones that run in

the middle of the the pin bones basically in the 
middle of the fillet you want to get that as well

you can kind of push them out with your fingers 
see how this and it almost looks like there wasn't

any but yes it is a messy ordeal but I find this 
really relaxing strangely it's like my yoga and

then once you've got your filets sort of deboned 
I'm just going to pull it apart into little chunks

now you might be one if I'm going to hack the 
fish up anyway why don't I just start picking

off the meat and you know remove the bones as they 
show up well like you could and that's what I used

to do but I find that you miss a lot of Bones by 
doing it systematically part by part I make sure

I don't leave any bones hidden so I know the back 
fins are gone now the belly is gone now the middle

is gone then that how you avoid having landmines 
and your fish and that is it I'm just going to

do one for now all we have left to do is make a 
simple garlic fried rice and assemble so I've got

a wok here and this is the same wok and oil that 
I used to fry my mackerel so that way I get you

know a little bit of fish flavors in my ring okay 
so I'm going to go in with some chopped garlic I

don't actually remember is that restaurant does 
their rice like this but this is how I'm going to

do it because I think it's delicious and once you 
notice that the smallest feasel of garlic starts

to turn brown I'm going to add my rice so this 
is just jasmine rice and you want to make sure it

wasn't cooked with too much water because that's 
how you're going to avoid clumpy mushy fried rice

so when I cook rice the fried rice it's always 
one part rice one part water at least to start

you can always add water but you can't take away 
I'm going to go in with some fish sauce because

and have enough fish sauce and just a little 
bit of sugar to balance the saltiness and that's

it I kind of keep tossing to distribute all the 
seasoning and I mean seriously this is such a good

base rice if you want to start you know getting

garlic and fish sauce really what could go wrong 
okay I think that is just about done all right

yes I know the rice doesn't look like anything

now the fun part when a squeeze some lime over

look so homey looking I mean you're not going 
to go to any Thai restaurant overseas they've

got this on the menu I can tell you that much 
so that smells good Wow really fresh delicious

flavors the fish is firm so it's got a bit of 
a chew to it in that contrast really well with

and it just reminds me so much of simple rustic
